section.p: A span object is an object which is contained within a ‘paragraph level’ (or block) object. It forms the markup of much of the text within the document.
In general, span objects can be nested within each other as required to create the reqired semantic meaning. Where this isn’t possible, it is stated in the descriptions below.
It is not possible to nest other types of object within span objects.

section.p: Semantic objects can be nested, and may contain any of the other span objects documented in this section within their span.

section.title: Keypresses
section.p: Keypresses allow key combinations to be documented, and consist of a list of key objects contained within an outer keypress object.

This structure allows output modes to join the key combinations as they see fit, and also format the keys as they see fit (for example rendering each key as its own key-cap, if that is appropriate). For example, the line above might appear in some modes as “Press Return or use Ctrl-M”; in this output mode, it appears as “Press Return or use CtrlM”.
The key objects can only contain plain text and entities: no other objects may be nested within them.

section.title: Menu entries
section.p: Menu entries allow selections from Wimp menus (or, indeed, any other sort of hierarchical menu structure) to be documented, and consist of a list of menu item objects contained within an outer menu object.

FileClose from the main menu, then choose Quit from the iconbar menu.
section.p:
This structure allows output modes to link the individual items in any way that they see fit. For example, the line above might be output as “Select 'File > Close' from the main menu, then choose 'Quit' from the iconbar menu”; in this output mode, it appears as “Select
File
Close from the main menu, then choose
Quit from the iconbar menu.”.
The item objects can only contain plain text and entities: no other objects may be nested within them.

section.title: External links
section.p: External links allow references to resources outside the document, to anything with a valid URI. The required URI is supplied using the href attribute within the link tag.

section.p: The optional external attribute can take the values true or false, with false being the default if the attribute is omitted. If true, output modes have the option to show the link as being ‘external’ if they have a way of doing so.

Some output modes, particularly those which don’t have a way to generate hyperlinks, can use an option to ’flatten’ the link. This can be controlled using the optional flatten attribute, which can take the values true or false and defaults to false if omitted. section.title: External definitions
section.p: The define object allows external definitions to be included within a document.

The name attribute identifies the definition to use, and the object will then be replaced by whatever value was passed to the -define parameter with the same name when XMLMan was called. For example, if the call was made with -define "date=2nd January 2025", then the output would be
section.code: This manual was created on 2nd January 2025.

section.title: Line breaks
section.p: Line breaks allow a new line to be forced within a section of text.
section.code:
This is some text.
And this will always be on the next line.

This will be a new paragraph.
section.p: This example will ensure that there is always a line break – without any paragraph spacing – after the first full stop.
